holidays.name: Collect Rocks Day
holidays.description: A day dedicated to appreciating the humble, fascinating world of rocks. Whether youâ€™re a serious collector or just like skipping stones, today is all about rocks!
holidays.origin: Unknown origin, likely started by rock enthusiasts to celebrate geology and natureâ€™s sculptures.
holidays.funFact: Some rocks have their own names and fan clubs, like the famous Half Dome in Yosemite or the Glossopteris fossil rocks.

holidays.name: International Chocolate Milkshake Day
holidays.description: Celebrate the classic indulgence that is the chocolate milkshake â€” creamy, chocolaty, and utterly delightful!
holidays.origin: Originated in the U.S. as a fun day for milkshake enthusiasts and diners alike to enjoy this sweet treat.
holidays.funFact: The first milkshakes date back to the 1880s, originally as alcoholic whiskey drinks before evolving into the kid-friendly classic drink.

holidays.name: Mexican Independence Day
holidays.description: A vibrant celebration marking Mexicoâ€™s independence from Spain in 1810, featuring parades, music, dancing, and fireworks!
holidays.origin: Commemorates the 'Grito de Dolores' by Miguel Hidalgo, the call to arms that started the Mexican War of Independence.
holidays.funFact: The celebrations officially begin on the night of September 15 with 'El Grito,' where the president reenacts Hidalgoâ€™s call from the balcony of the National Palace in Mexico City.

holidays.name: Play-Doh Day
holidays.description: Honoring the iconic modeling compound that has inspired creativity and messy fun for generations of kids and adults alike.
holidays.origin: Celebrated on September 16 because Play-Doh was first trademarked in 1956 on this day.
holidays.funFact: Play-Doh was originally created as a wallpaper cleaner before kids discovered it as a modeling clay!
